date_text: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2025
body: This tastes delicious just like boba, BUT OMG the caffeine in it killed my stomach. I drank it this morning around 8am and it‚Äôs 10pm and I‚Äôm still suffering from anxiety and stomach pain, I took some magnesium but it worked for only a short time.  I had it last night and it took me a bit to fall asleep but I had taken Magnesium and melatonin. I don‚Äôt think I could drink this again unless I was about to run or do something super super active. It makes me sad because I was happy it tasted good and the macros aren‚Äôt bad and it‚Äôs a good amount in the package.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars
author: Travista
date_text: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2025
body: Pretty good. Its obviously not a 1 to 1 taste to normal (with sugar) milk tea. Its just the monk fruit that has a "taste". If you're use to alternative sweeteners or monk fruit i don't think you would notice the taste so this would be a perfect. I stop noticing the flavor discrepancy after 2-4 sips then it taste completely fine. Do not try using boiling water or anything hot to dissolve or mix this will make the protein powder curdle and it'll be like drinking cottage cheese. I did this and gave the product the benefit of the doubt after googling how protein powder works. If it clumps most likely whatever you used as your liquid was to hot. Have had deliciously smooth drinks dissolving the powder is faucet warm, room temp,and cold liquids.
variant: Flavor Name: Classic Milk Tea Size: 25 Servings

date_text: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2025
body: The taste is off and not appealing. I lived in Hong Kong for a while and know what Vietnamese coffee tastes like. I am by no means a coffee snob; I like instant coffee. Experimenting, trying lots of different ways to make coffee has caused me like a wide variety of flavors. Unfortunately there is something off about the taste of this. I‚Äôm going to guess it‚Äôs the monk fruit sweeter??? Not sure. I don‚Äôt think I have refined pallet and didnt think I would notice anything off about the taste. But it‚Äôs so bad I‚Äôm not sure what I‚Äôll do with the bag :(

author: Cindy
date_text: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2025
body: The order came in pretty quick, I'll say it got at my house within three days. When I opened the bag, the powder smelled very delicious, sorta like Chocolate-flavored Nesquik. I used a blender to make mine with a cup of water and a cup of Oat milk which is very delicious. I don't see any issue with any clumsiness. It does get a bit foamy but I believe it's due to the blender. The other day, I had some regular milk tea at the mall and nearly couldn't finish it because it was so sweet. I really like how Boba Tea Protein is not very sweet but still very delicious and easy to drink. It is also low in calories compared to other protein drinks. I will definitely buy more flavors just so I have more to choose from.

author: Rachel Borchelt
date_text: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2025
body: Why did you pick this product vs others?: Second purchase --- the regular Milk Tea is a favorite in our house! It is one of the best tasting protein powders I have ever tried by itself (typically, powders feel too chalky or have a chemical aftertaste and I get none of that from this), but I like to mix it with a dab of creamer and a squirt of peach mio for my go-to morning drink. I do typically mix it in a blender but have never had issues with consistency. Also have tried hot coffee in it; just be aware if the coffee is too hot you will separate the milk powder. Taste: It tastes like a sweet milk by itself. Hard to tell it's a protein powder once mixed into water or milk. Mixability: It has become the base for a protein-packed breakfast drink in our house. Coffee, matcha powder, different flavor drink enhancers, flavored creamer all can be combined in it.

I didn't get any of that reminiscent ‚Äúmilk tea‚Äù taste or flavor like I would from a boba tea store (like Lan Fong Yuen in Hong Kong). This product tasted more like a sweet cereal milk (like the overly sweet milk you get after you eat half a box of sugary of Frosted Flakes). I‚Äôm chef trying to eat healthier, but I didn‚Äôt quite feel healthy after drinking this with the recommended 1 scoop right before working a dinner a service. The only thing I did enjoy about this specific flavor was that it mixed well with an already made cup of milk tea or a strong dark overly steeped tea, and that I would poop so good after! I‚Äôve tried a few of the other Boba Protein products and those seemed okay, however, this particular product wasn‚Äôt worth the value for the money and the quality of flavor wasn‚Äôt there either.

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars
author: Shan
date_text: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2025
body: Boba Tea Protein Vietnamese Coffee is one of those experimental products that I really wanted to like‚Äîbut just couldn‚Äôt. From the first sip, I knew this was going to be a struggle. The flavor struck me as overwhelmingly artificial, with a strange bitterness and a lingering chalky sweetness that made it hard to finish even half a serving. I expected something that reminded me of a rich Vietnamese iced coffee, but what I got was closer to a miscalibrated protein shake with hints of coffee extract and something chemically sweet. Honestly, I gagged. I found the price‚Äî$49.99‚Äîto be almost insulting. For that cost, I expect either an exceptional flavor or nutritional payoff. This gave me neither. The idea of combining 25g of grass-fed whey protein isolate with boba tea elements sounds innovative, but in practice, it just doesn‚Äôt work. You end up with a drink that satisfies neither craving: it‚Äôs not rich and creamy like boba tea, and it‚Äôs not clean and neutral like a proper protein shake. It‚Äôs the worst of both worlds, and at this price point, it feels like a waste of money. I did try to salvage it. I mixed it with milk, added ice, blended it into a smoothie, even tried masking it with cinnamon or cocoa powder‚Äîbut nothing made the flavor tolerable. The drink has a weird after-feel that made my teeth feel squeaky and unpleasantly coated, possibly from the monk fruit sweetener or coconut oil creamer. The gritty texture never really went away either, no matter how well I shook or blended it. The worst part is that it left me feeling unsatisfied and slightly annoyed. I kept thinking: if I want boba tea, I‚Äôll get a real one. If I want a protein shake, there are far better, more palatable options. Combining the two sounds fun in theory, but this version didn‚Äôt deliver. It felt like the product was trying too hard to be trendy without nailing the basics of taste and drinkability. I‚Äôm giving this product 1.5 out of 5 stars, mostly because the nutritional content and ingredient transparency are solid on paper‚Äîbut the execution failed spectacularly. I just couldn‚Äôt bring myself to keep drinking it, and most of it ended up in the trash.
variant: Flavor Name: Vietnamese Coffee Size: 19 Servings

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars
author: David
date_text: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2025
body: I saw this on many many ads and I love milk tea, so I decided I had to try it. The price was on the high side, considering I could get Optimum Nutrition for way less money and I go through protein fairly quickly. I thought about it for a while until I decided to just go for it. I mixed it like the instructions said, 4oz water / 4 oz milk + 1 scoop of powder. I had very high expectations given all the 5 star reviews, but now I'm wondering whether all those people were either 1) shills, 2) never had milk tea in their lives. There is a strong tea taste somewhere in there I'll give you that, but it does not taste like the black milk tea you can get at a boba shop. Drinking this leaves a strong bitter lingering note in my mouth after taking a few sips (from the black tea) so that's also a downside. All in all it doesn't come anywhere near satisfying my milk tea cravings. I think I would be better off brewing the tea at home myself and adding fairlife + whey powder to make my own milk tea protein drink. I can see what they were trying to do, but this is just not it. I don't think I'll ever be buying this again. I guess I still need to finish the bag so we'll see if this grows on me. But for now I give it maybe a 2.5 / 5, and being generous I rounded up to a 3.
variant: Flavor Name: Classic Milk Tea Size: 25 Servings

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars
author: Alyssa
date_text: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2025
body: Taste wise - It's pretty delicious and just like a coffee latte especially with milk which makes it so creamy and dreamy. Unfortunately there is the classic alternative sugar aftertaste. It doesn't use Stevia but it's very similar to the type of aftertaste you get from that. I'm guessing it's from the Monk Fruit alternative sugar. For me the strong coffee taste does kind of cover it up and counteract it pretty well but it's still obviously there. Still love the taste. Mixing - The powder does not dissolve easily which is my main con for this. You absolutely need a shaker bottle as recommended and shake a lot and vigorously or it will not dissolve. It's pricey, but you get a huge generously sized bag. Not sure why it's called boba tea when this has no boba and isn't even tea, but delicious way to get your protein!
variant: Flavor Name: Vietnamese Coffee Size: 19 Servings

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars
author: Robin
date_text: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2025
body: I was surprised on just how much this actually tasted and smelled like coffee! I expected it to be more "flavored" like other protein products, but this was surprisingly strong and tasty.  I'd even recommend trying this with milk instead of water since it'll add to that flavor.  I can taste a bit of the coconut creamer that is used in this blend, though I have trouble picking out the monk fruit sweetner.  While the price is a bit higher than some other protein products, I can see myself absolutely buying this again since I think it's hard to find a protein blend that actually tastes good.
variant: Flavor Name: Vietnamese Coffee Size: 19 Servings

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars
author: AutoxSTI
date_text: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2025
body: This boba tea mix makes for a great tasting drink.  The original intent of this is to make bubble tea, but since I didn't have any available at the time, I decided to try it without adding the boba.  Even without it, it makes a great drink.  Has the classic flavor of Vietnamese coffee without the hassle.  Just add warm water and you're good to go.  Comes in a huge over two pound bag to make a lot of coffees.  Also nice is that it provides a good amount of whey protein to supplement your diet.  Also nice is that it uses monk fruit instead of added sugar for sweetness.
variant: Flavor Name: Vietnamese Coffee Size: 19 Servings

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars
author: Silverbullet875
date_text: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2025
body: So, this is a giant bag! I was surprised exactly how big it was. The scoop is REALLY big. I really like the coffee flavor, but it is very strong. I've learned that I prefer to use less than a scoop in my drinks. There is a bit of sweetener aftertaste as well. But not enough to turn me off of it. I like to use it in almond milk as well as my overnight oats/chia pudding concoction I make. I mix it in with a frother and it blends with no problem using this method. No weird grittiness. This big bag should last me a long time!
variant: Flavor Name: Vietnamese Coffee Size: 19 Servings

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars
author: Buttercup
date_text: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2025
body: Boba Tea Protein has a whopping 25g of protein in each serving. The resealable bag holds 32 ounces of sandy colored powder made up of 100% grass-fed whey protein isolate, coconut oil creamer, 100% Vietnamese Robusta Coffee, monk fruit extract, and salt. To make a serving you just need to mix 1 scoop of powder with 8-10 ounces of chilled water and shake in a protein shaker cup. You can also use various combinations of milk (traditional or plant based) and water to change the consistency and make it creamier. I opted to use 10¬†ounces of chilled water. The powder dissolved easily and left no residue at the base of the cup. It had an intoxicating and inviting aroma of coffee. The drink is light and the initial flavor is a delicious coffee.  But the sip transforms and finishes on a very cloyingly sweet note that coated my palate and remained strong long after I had finished the drink. I am guessing this is from the inclusion of monk fruit extract. This is the part of the drink that I was not a fan of. There are 25 servings per bag with each 1 scoop serving (37.4g) containing 150 Calories, 3g Total Fat, 6g Total Carbohydrate, and 25g Protein. It is Manufactured in the USA. It is a soy-free, gluten free, and grain free product. The product that I received has a best by date of 20 months from the date that I received it.¬†Overall, I loved that it had such a tasty coffee flavor but sadly the monk fruit extract overwhelmed this flavor and the drink finished on a cloyingly sweet note. I just wish that the drink was made with raw sugar as I think it would have been a better option.
variant: Flavor Name: Vietnamese Coffee Size: 19 Servings

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars

date_text: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2025
body: I'm a bubble tea head. And this protein shake doesn't make me feel guilty to enjoy it every single day. Honestly, it tastes strange to me at first. Perhaps because I'm not used to the monk fruit sweetener. But it grew on me, and now I'm really looking forward to it everyday. I don't like my drink too sweet. So my ratio is 5oz almond milk, 5 oz water, boba tea protein, cooked boba, ice. Shake for 30 seconds then enjoy!

body: This boba tea protein coffee drink mix is easy to prepare and tastes good. The powder dissolves easily in water. No gritty texture. It has a nice, sweet coffee flavor. It is smooth and fairly creamy. The added grass-fed whey protein is great. I like that it is low in sugar and lactose. Sweetened with monk fruit extract. It contains 112mg of natural caffeine per serving. This comes in a large, resealable, foil-lined standup retail bag. A scoop is provided for easy measuring. Overall, I really like this. It is a great protein coffee drink to have when I need a little pick-me-up in the afternoon. It is energizing and fairly filling. For around $2 per serving, it seems like a pretty decent value for the money. Made in USA.

body: I adore this Boba Tea Protein Vietnamese Coffee. I can get my afternoon coffee fix/pick me up AND a whopping 25gs of protein in one shake! It mixes easily and the texture is smooth, not gritty. The coffee is strong and sweet, very tasty. The downside is it's 150 calories per scoop but as long as you're aware and considering it in your daily caloric intake, it's no big deal. title: 4.0 out of 5 stars
author: JKremmer Fitness
date_text: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2025
body: If you‚Äôre after a boba-inspired protein shake, Boba Tea Protein nails the flavor. It‚Äôs Truly Grass Fed-certified, 99.99% lactose-free, and mixes smoothly without the chalky texture of lower-quality proteins. With 25g of protein per serving, it‚Äôs a solid pick for daily protein intake‚Äîbut not the best choice for post-workout recovery. What You Need to Know Before Buying: ‚úî Tastes Like Real Milk Tea ‚Äì Smooth, creamy, and lightly sweet with no stevia aftertaste. ‚úî High-Quality Whey Isolate ‚Äì Boba Tea Protein sources its whey from Irish grass-fed dairy. ‚úî Contains Caffeine ‚Äì Classic Milk Tea has 121mg per serving, which might not be ideal after workouts. ‚úî Easy to Mix ‚Äì Dissolves well in a shaker bottle with minimal clumping. Why Not 5 Stars? Not the Best for Recovery ‚Äì The fat content (4g) and caffeine could slow digestion post-workout. Protein Efficiency is Lower ‚Äì With 66% protein per serving, it‚Äôs less efficient than other isolates at this price. If you‚Äôre looking for a high-protein milk tea alternative, Boba Tea Protein is a great option. Just know it‚Äôs more about flavor than muscle recovery. Final Grade: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚ú® (4.5/5) Would I buy it again? Yes‚Äîfor taste. Not as a post-workout shake.

body: I've ordered this several times it's really good. Pros: clean ingredients with monkfruit used to sweeten it. Taste like actual milk tea, not too sweet. Mixes well with just water. Cons: has caffiene. Would be nice if there was a decaf version. Because of the caffeine it's only good for the mornings. If I haven't had my protein shake I can't use this mid day...so if you're sensitive to caffeine this is something you would need to consider. Having tried their taro and Vietnamese coffee flavors I can confidently say this is the only drinkable one. The others are way too sweet and taste/smell weird. If you're looking for something so scratch to boba tea itch, classic milk tea is the way to go.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars
author: Michelle Mac
date_text: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2025
body: Texture/Mixability I don't know what everyone else was experiencing but how I got it to mix very well is by getting 6 oz of hot water from my Keurig. I then heated up a mason jar (just put under hot tap water so it doesn't crack when you put in the hot water from the Keurig/tea kettle/etc.) put in your 6 oz of hot water in. I then have one of those metal blender balls, I put it in the mason jar. On the bag it says to use one scoop, however I liked using half of a scoop, I like the taste better. I then put the lid on and shake, it literally takes maybe 5-10 sec of shaking to see visibly no clumps, I do it for an additional 20 sec just to be sure. Then put it into ice, and then add your choice of milk. By doing all of that, the Mixability and texture is 10/10, no gross grittiness, clumps, or gross aftertaste. I even like to add a little creamer or strawberry syrup to give it a little more sweetness or different flavor. Taste- If you don't like black tea, this isn't for you. It tastes much like black tea. It's not an overwhelming taste. Value for money- Now I don't know if it is, since I just got it, however, because I like it as half of a scoop it could get me close to 50 servings instead of the 25.
